comments.html: In the scenario with a DMVPN built over the Internet and the need for redundancy, in the past I have used the Front-Door VRF DMVPN feature, with the Internet interface in the front-door VRF.  This will only work if you are full tunneling Internet traffic from spokes to hub sites, but it solved the issue of having to have 2 different default routes for Internet and one for tunneled traffic quite nicely.
comments.name: Sam Crooks

comments.html: Front-door VRF works nicely if you have the spoke site with link to one ISP (or two ISPs that don't do RPF check). If you have two uplinks to two ISPs, you have to use two VRFs (or tunnel route selection if you use two MPLS/VPN services and don't need IPSec).
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: we use a vrf per ISP each with a different default route in each, and a 3rd default route in the global table for traffic going through the tunnels
